I truly tried to get into Dispatcher. The game looks great! The sea monster creature looked scary the first couple times, but then like the game it grew old. At first it took me awhile to learn the controls and mechanics of the game. With the detailed character creator I had a nagging suspicion that I was missing something. Somehow I wasn't playing my engineer right. Quickly I learned that was not the case.

The game past it's character creator is entirely simple and poorly balanced. The fact I went engineer meant absolutely nothing to the game. You gain no special abilities, no access to tools others would be without, no entry into areas that a scientist or pilot would be denied.  It's just stats, and so you'd better make sure you make great choices because you'll never be able to level up in the game.

The game relies not on experience but a currency you pick up throughout the maps. No problem there except you must survive in order to carry over the money you've found to be able to level your character up. That runs into a major issue since survival is almost impossible once the monster sees you and it will see you.

Once spotted you must run, but there is no means of escape, no means to halt the creatures progress or to slow it down. It can follow you into duct and once it has you confirmed it will not let go. There is no way to lure the creature elsewhere when you enter its patrol area. Essentially the game is a chase simulator with no mechanics other than running.

As I said I tried to get into the game, but with no means of progression, the monster stale, the game gets incredibly boring. Perhaps it would be fun online, but no one plays the multiplayer. Although the multiplayer is a good way to give yourself multiple lives.

In the end the game could have improved itself in a number of ways. It could have included NPCs that the game seems more than capable of rendering in funny hunt, but are entirely missing in single player. Even as cannon fodder they'd provide a great distraction.  There are no abilities, the monster isn't hampered by in world hazards nor are you capable of exploiting them to your advantage. That's the theme with this game it feels as if there are all these features that can be added, that are meant to be there, but just aren't.

Not Recommended

reviewText:
Dispatcher:
~~~~~~~~~

You are on board the spaceship “Dispatcher” which is drifting into deep space after an unfortunate accident. To make it worse, not only have the few survivors been affected, but Aliens seem to have found a way onto the vessel. Armed with a flashlight, you have to try to survive as long as you can in this atmospheric horror game!

First you have to create a crew member (your character). You will have several classes to choose from: pilot, signalman, engineer, scientist, and two others who you can unlock (which I haven’t yet). Then you have to choose your biography (I like this, it’s fun) everything from a farmer, fanatic, idiot or alcoholic to an actor who likes to play movies in his/her birthday suit (absolutely mind blowing). Each biography has its own attribute… cough…cough!

You will be able to play 2 modes in single player - Survival or Funny Hunt. In the survival mode, you will have to survive as long as you can and escape the vessel. In the funny hunt, you will play the monster and hunt survivors (the A.I is not that great in this mode). A multiplayer mode is also available.

When you setup a survival game, you can choose the level of difficulty, from No Monsters to Hard. I suggest trying the first couple of games on the easy difficulty as you do not have any tutorials on this game. You can also choose if you have an unlimited number of batteries for your flashlight and you can elect to have infection or not.

During the gameplay, you can pick up items: batteries for your flashlight, pills to regenerate your health, money, red and blue keys to open doors (that need one of these colour keys to open), notes and fuses. Be careful what you step onto, as there are a number of dangers: Explosive mines… (well, you know what will happen if you step on one of those). Electric mines (will not kill you but if you being chased by a monster, you will be in a bit of a strife): Green slime (this is radioactive and you will lose a fair bit of your health).

Four enemies to be worried about include a glowing red orb - one touch and its game over!

The graphics are good and I really like the horror ambiance in this game.

There are a couple of issues. The resolution can’t go higher than 1920 X 1080 or the screen will be cut. There are some items that can’t be pick up. For me the most annoying thing is the sensitivity on the mouse wheel button (please change this, make it part of the setup). However, the developers seems to be on the ball and are trying to resolve issues rapidly.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Good graphics
-	Great ambiance – Horror theme
-	Good character customization with humour
-	Challenging
-	Trading cards & achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	A bit buggy
-	Mouse sensitivity – please remove it from the mouse wheel button

Despite a need for some improvements, I am enjoying this game and I am very happy to recommend it!

7.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dispatcher is a first person horror rpg by Civil Savages, where you are stuck on an abandoned spacecraft with an alien... sound familiar? Well, because it's the plot of 'Alien' and the recent title 'Alien Isolation'. Not that this is a bad thing, the idea of creating suspense with a secluded area and a few enemies creates magnificent tension. Which is done extremely well here.

https://youtu.be/arqgFNgrfRo?t=24m43s

Using the Unreal 4 Engine, Civil Savages creates a very immersive and beautiful looking game. The mechanics are fairly typical of this genre. First person control, pills to heal, batteries for your flashlight, and interactable objects. However, you don't come to a first person horror game for deep crazy mechanics. You come for the exploration, the jump scares, and the challenge of getting out alive. One thing that stands out as different for the gameplay is the rpg mechanics. Which are implemented in an almost roguelike way.

The first thing you do before playing is create a character and choose between 7 (5 available at start, one unlockable) careers. It's basically who are you on this ship. So you can be a scientist, signalman, engineer, etc. Each class has their own starting stats (Energy, Reaction, Stamina, Immunity, Quiet) that affect your character. After choosing your career, you then must choose from  12 different biographies. These are what you were before you were assigned to the ship. Each of these give you character a little flavor, but also change stats and add static effects in some cases. As you go through each playthrough you will earn money which can then be spent to increase each of the individual stats. Making the game have that roguelike feel.

Being in early access there are some bugs I ran into, like falling through the world in the practice area. So be prepared for optimization coming down the pipeline from Civil Savages. They are also planning to add a co-op mode to the game at some point this summer which I find to be an exciting take on the first person horror genre.

Overall, Dispatcher is on it's way to being a strong competitor in the horror market, with great graphics, atmosphere, and character, you'll be sure to have your share of scares.

reviewText:
If I were to describe Dispatcher -- a survival horror game developed by CivilSavages – in a single sentence, it would have to be: “Dispatcher is a poor man’s Alien: Isolation”

You play as a crew member on the space ship Dispatcher. But something has gone wrong, and a sinister extra-terrestrial being is now on the hunt for every human aboard, including you. It is your goal to evacuate yourself off of the Dispatcher and escape the horrors of space and its predator.

That’s the basic gist of the game. You’ll be collecting pill bottles to restore health, batteries to keep your flashlight alive, notes, key cards, power fuses and so on; all the while being hunted by the monsters.

But here’s the thing… this game is cheap as all hell. I can’t tell you how many times an alien spotted me from who-knows where, only to chase me down and kill me before I could even flinch. Their ability to spot and chase the player is stupidly quick, and you won’t have a chance to react before getting eaten alive. Hiding in vents, behind objects or any sort of barrier is a total waste of time. The only way to properly evade your pursuer is to lock yourself inside a storage closet or bathroom, and if you aren’t situated directly next to one of these rooms… well, you’re dead. There’s even an enemy who looks like a floating red orb, and the very second it touches you, its game over. Its things like these that make the game less horrifying and more irritating. And don’t get me started on the plethora of traps scattered across the Dispatcher. Mines, radioactive sludge, even electrified explosives. When the player is running from the monster, he/she won’t be looking down at the floor to avoid hazards. It’s just another cheap mechanic to get you killed.

As mentioned before, the player’s only objective is to find keycards and fuses to open specific doors, but the ship’s layout is so basic and similar that it’ll take you ten minutes before realizing you’ve been walking in a circle.

But thankfully, there are some pros to this game. Sound design is top notch, there is a unique and fun character creation mechanic that RPG fans will feel right at home with, there’s multiplayer, and the Unreal engine looks better than ever.

But with all this game’s short comings, I just don’t see the worth in Dispatcher. The entirety of its content can be played in one of Alien: Isolation’s DLC survival missions, and it’s far more frustrating than it is scary.

To sum it up, Dispatcher still feels like it’s in early access, and what it sets out to achieve has already been done by better horror games.

reviewText:
IntroductionDispatcher is a sci-fi horror game that has you roaming around in the dark searching for notes and to find a way out of the 'Dispatcher' while being chased by monsters.

GameplayFor a game like Dispatcher, you would expect it to be a typical run away from monsters in a linear type of way, whereby you are running to where the game wants you to go. The first thing that I didn't really expect from a game like this is a custom character that you can create from the start of the game. There is a nice variation of what characters you can be, this also with some cool traits that your character can have, and even some different voice options. Although this isn't really needed in a horror game, it's still a nice feature to have on a specific type of genre that doesn't normally have character customization. The traits that you can pick will increase or decrease your overall score of these: Energy, Speed, Stamina, Immunity and Quiet. Although it seems like some of these attridbutes don't really change the gameplay all that much. I have tested the game and have changed the amount of Stamina, speed ect I have but didn't really see much difference in the game itself. Upon playing the game for the first time you will start off with a few options in the game to either make the game harder or easier depending on how you like to play your games. The level design for Dispatcher is well thought out, although may be on the linear side of things the game itself is very good and the level design seems to be well thought out. Although there isn't much orginiality to the game, it's still fairly nice to play. The atmosphere is well presented, along with some nice sound effects along with it.

The graphics of this game are rather impressive, the lighting of this game is very good. It's just light enough to keep the game interesting, especially when you hear a unexpected monster creeps up on you. The graphics of the game in general are very suiting for the type of sci-fi genre that the game is going for. With the nice lights that are on some blocks and the that the walls look fit the genre of the game very well, giving it that futuristic feel to the game. Although the graphics are fairly nice, the one thing that I noticed was there was no option to change motion blur on or off for the game. This may annoy users who don't like the use of motion blur and therefor are forced to play with it on.

Pros+ Atmosphere is great
+ Lighting of the game is well done
+ Level design is well thought out
+ Trading Cards & Achievements

Cons- No option to change motion blur
- No controller support

Result / Final thoughtsDispatcher is a fairly decent horror game. It has great graphics and lighting that are really done well throughout the game. The graphics, along with the well thought out level deisgn and monsters really make this game good. Although the game seems to be better suited with full controller support, it is still a great game and well worth the price.

Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tl; dr- It's a scary game. With puzzles to do as well! Basically, it's Amensia with a dash of Fallout in space. If you like being scared while trying to figure out puzzles, this is the game for you.

Without a doubt, Dispatcher is scary. Given its a horror game, that's a good start, but that's the thing done best so far about Dispatcher. It combines jump scares, with the shuffling sounds of the infected crew member to keep you on edge. You can't fight back, and all you can do is hope it never finds you.

Beyond the scare factor, Dispatcher is also part a puzzle game and part an RPG. You get to choose a class for your character, and then traits for it, which helps define your skills (and more importantly, how quiet you are!). The puzzle part comes in with the level design- you need to finish the level and escape, while avoiding the infected crew member/alien (not really sure what it is at this stage). So to do so, you've got to open locked doors, find key cards, etc.

Considering how early the game is right now, this game is looking pretty amazing. It looks brilliant, and the lack of lighting really creates that atmosphere needed for a decent scary game. When you combine the scare factor with the puzzle nature, and the RPG element, you've got the potential for a great game here.

The only issues you'll find with the game so far are the translations, which are mostly in Russian still, or in badly done English (you can still make out what they mean however, so its not an impediment), and the lack of a tutorial or help system (they offer a practice mode ingame, but it's another puzzle section that is more guided, without actually using any words. You've really got no idea what you're doing first up, so it'll take a few attempts to get going. It's an easy game to pick up though, so you'll be fine.

Right now, it's extremely early access. You'll get some fun out of the game right now, but not an infinite amount, so purchasing it now is more to support the developers so they can finish this game.
